label: Letter from William Davies to Nathanael Greene
description: Letter from William Davies to Nathanael Greene discussing the shortage of various supplies and troops. Colonel Davies debates the movements of several regiments of men in regards to military strategy and what movement would provide the most strength in the desired areas. Davies also reports the instability of the government in the states of South Carolina, North Carolina, Virginia, and [New] Hampshire.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
[William Davies to Nathanael Greene
June 2, 1781
[RvW Box 1 Folder 11; MSS. â€“ A.L.S.]]

Charlottesville June 2, 1781
Sir,
I am but just returned from attending
the Baron, and am not yet able to say he is in readi;
ness to march. Shoes and some other articles of cloath-
ing he has not yet got; and cartridge boxes are
very much wanting. I think the former may be
procured; but I doubt our ability to furnish the latter.
The incursions of the enemy have thrown every
thing into great confusion, as well as filled the
minds of the people with the greatest discontent
particularly with Baron Steuben, as they think
he is disposed to leave them without assistance.
It is a cause of great dissatisfaction that the
new levies should be taken out of the State, when
their presence is so much wanting in it. The dis-
stance from hence to you is such that I fear
many letters are intercepted, and that the true
situation of this country is unknown to you.
Indeed, I have often thought it was very dangerous
for the secrets of government and the designs of the
commanding generals to be so much exposed to 
the knowledge of the enemy, as they always will
be till a proper cypher is adopted. At present there
[End Page 1]
is very little information here of the real state of
southern affairs, or of the immediate necessity of
the march of a reinforcement to you, while
this State is attacked with so numerous a
body of the enemy. This is the general talk. For
my own part I am much at a loss what to deter-
mine. The support of your army is nearly con-
nected with the security of this State and the safety
of the stores. At present the Marquis is much in-
ferior in number of men, and the stores are
in great danger: yet if the Baron on the other
hand should join him, he would still be in-
ferior and not able to secure them. Should he
march to you, it would probably give you so
decided a superiority, for a while at least,
as perhaps to enable government to be reinstu-
ted in South Carolina, and more firmly established
in the North State. This I think would have a con
siderable influence in Europe, when the world saw
that altho' the enemy overrun the Southern State
one after the other, yet the moment they left
them, they lost them. I am, however, much
disturbed at the refractory conduct of some
of our own citizens. Augusta and some
other counties have refused the draft, and 
[End Page 2]
in Hampshire they have made an open insur-
rection, with a considerable number in arms.
General Morgan has march'd against them,
and it is reported altho' much doubted that
he has dispersed them, hanged some and
confined others.
We have had two or three supplies of
arms from the northward, purchased
by the State, I hope it will enable us to
defend ourselves something better than
we have hitherto done; tho' I am very ap-
prehensive such arrangements will be
adopted this session of Assembly as wil[l]
ma[ke] matters worse than ever.
I have the honor to be, Sir, with [the]
greatest respect and esteem,
Your most obedient hble Servt. [humble Servant]
William Davies
[End Page 3]
[Endorsed: note written upside down]
This with other Letters which accompany it I recd. about
one Hour Agoo [sic], Now forwarded to Charlotte, 7 [pm] Special
Express Seven oClock--------- P.M June 26th 1781
[From Salisbury]. John Dunn Dist QMG
[Addressed:]
[public service]
Honorable Major General Greene
express
Head quarters -
[seal]
[Endorsed: written upside down]
From Col. [Colonel] Davies
June 2d. 1781.
[End Page 4]
